content: Dig a small hole in the soil. Use a trowel or spade to dig a hole 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) deep. Break up the soil within the hole and remove any twigs or foreign debris. Fill the hole with water. Use distilled (not spring) water. You can find this in your local pharmacy. Rainwater is slightly acidic, and bottled or tap water tends to be slightly alkaline. Fill the hole until you have a muddy pool at the bottom. Insert the test probe into the mud. Make sure your tester is clean and calibrated (for a more exact measurement). Wipe the probe with a tissue or clean cloth, and insert it into the mud. Hold it there for 60 seconds and take a reading. pH is usually measured on a scale of 1-14, though the tester may not include this entire range. A pH of 7 indicates neutral soil. A pH above 7 indicates alkaline soil. A pH below 7 indicates acidic soil. Take several measurements in different spots in the garden. A single reading may be an anomaly, so it's good to get an idea of the average pH in a plot. If they're all around the same, take the average and amend the soil accordingly. If one spot is very different than the rest, however, you may need to "spot treat" it. Purchase pH test strips. Test strips, also known as litmus paper, are a quick and easy way to measure the pH of your soil. You can purchase them online or at your local garden store. [1] Mix a handful of soil with room-temperature distilled water. Take a handful of the soil you’d like to test and put it in a bowl. Then, pour some distilled water into the bowl until the dirt is the consistency of a milkshake. You can give the mixture a stir to ensure the water is fully incorporated. [2] Dip a pH test strip in the mixture for 20-30 seconds. Holding your pH test strip at the non-reading end, dip the strip into the dirt mixture for 20-30 seconds. This test time can vary, so consult the directions on your specific test strips to determine the proper dipping time. When the test time is up, lift the pH strip from the water, and dip it briefly in distilled water to clean off the dirt. Compare your pH strip to the test kit’s key. Use the key included in your pH test kit to read the pH of your soil. Normally this key is color-coded. Compare your strip to the colors available, and select the one that most resembles your result. The key will equate this color with the pH number of your soil. [3] Make your soil less acidic. If your soil pH tested below 7, add a cup of dolomite or quick lime to the soil. Mix well, then retest with your probe. Use this method to slowly change the pH of your soil. Wood ash in moderation helps as well. Both are available at local gardening centers. Follow the advice in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these substances you will need to add to achieve the desired pH. If you need to change your soil pH level more than one full point, contact a local gardening professional. They can help you calibrate your soil so it can be amended most successfully. [4] Make your soil less alkaline. If your soil pH tested above 7, add a cup of organic matter, such as pine needles, peat moss, or decomposed tree leaves. Then, retest the soil to gauge the new pH. Add additional cups, testing as necessary, until you reach the desired level. Sulfur is very effective as well. Use the instructions in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these additives you will need to add to achieve your desired pH. If your soil needs to be adjusted more than a full pH point, contact a local gardening or landscaping professional. They can help you calibrate your soil to the right level through an on-site evaluation. [5] Change your soil pH to suit specific plants. For example, add sulfur to a certain area of your garden to encourage beautiful blue blooms on your hydrangeas, which prefer more acidic soils. The pH of your soil does not need to be uniform your entire garden over; feel free to alter it to support different plants. You can consult the Old Farmer’s Almanac to determine the best pH for your particular garden. Some plants prefer a pH of 7 while some fruits favor a lower pH.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Test-Soil-pH">How to Test Soil pH</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Andrew Carberry</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Testing_Soil_pH_with_a_Commercial_Test_Probe_sub" id="">Testing Soil pH with a Commercial Test Probe</a>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=andrewcarberry#andrewcarberry">Andrew Carberry</a>. Andrew Carberry has been working with school gardens and farm to school programs since 2008. He is now a Program Associate at Winrock International, where he works on the Community Based Food Systems Team.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">5 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Do you want to <a href="/Plant-Your-First-Garden" title="Plant Your First Garden">plant a garden</a>? Then it is important to know about the pH of your soil. The pH is a measure of the soil's acidity or alkalinity. Different plants require different pH levels to thrive. Once you know your soil's pH, you can adjust your garden accordingly to help your plants grow. Getting a measurement is easy, and there are a number of different ways to do it.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Testing_Soil_pH_with_a_Commercial_Test_Probe_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Testing_Soil_pH_with_a_Commercial_Test_Probe">Testing Soil pH with a Commercial Test Probe</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_dd925ab4a7" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_dd925ab4a7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-1-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Dig-a-Hole" title="Dig a Hole">Dig</a> a small hole in the soil.</b> Use a trowel or spade to dig a hole 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) deep. Break up the soil within the hole and remove any twigs or foreign debris.

<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_aa3ffa97d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_aa3ffa97d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-2-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Fill the hole with water.</b> Use distilled (not spring) water. You can find this in your local pharmacy. Rainwater is slightly acidic, and bottled or tap water tends to be slightly alkaline. Fill the hole until you have a muddy pool at the bottom.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_a188223d85" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a188223d85')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-3-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Insert the test probe into the mud.</b> Make sure your tester is clean and calibrated (for a more exact measurement). Wipe the probe with a tissue or clean cloth, and insert it into the mud.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_9976a7476a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9976a7476a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-4-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Hold it there for 60 seconds and take a reading.</b> pH is usually measured on a scale of 1-14, though the tester may not include this entire range.

<ul>
<li>A pH of 7 indicates neutral soil.</li>
<li>A pH above 7 indicates alkaline soil.</li>
<li>A pH below 7 indicates acidic soil.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_e10ccb35ba" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e10ccb35ba')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-5-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take several measurements in different spots in the garden.</b> A single reading may be an anomaly, so it's good to get an idea of the average pH in a plot. If they're all around the same, take the average and amend the soil accordingly. If one spot is very different than the rest, however, you may need to "spot treat" it.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Paper_Test_Strips_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Paper_Test_Strips">Using Paper Test Strips</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_22eb2c884a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_22eb2c884a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Purchase pH test strips.</b> Test strips, also known as litmus paper, are a quick and easy way to measure the pH of your soil. You can purchase them online or at your local garden store.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_1f8f4aa704" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1f8f4aa704')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-7-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix a handful of soil with room-temperature distilled water.</b> Take a handful of the soil you’d like to test and put it in a bowl. Then, pour some distilled water into the bowl until the dirt is the consistency of a milkshake. You can give the mixture a stir to ensure the water is fully incorporated.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_4af9450309" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4af9450309')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-8-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Dip a pH test strip in the mixture for 20-30 seconds.</b> Holding your pH test strip at the non-reading end, dip the strip into the dirt mixture for 20-30 seconds. This test time can vary, so consult the directions on your specific test strips to determine the proper dipping time. When the test time is up, lift the pH strip from the water, and dip it briefly in distilled water to clean off the dirt.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_d6298af28e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d6298af28e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-9-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Compare your pH strip to the test kit’s key.</b> Use the key included in your pH test kit to read the pH of your soil. Normally this key is color-coded. Compare your strip to the colors available, and select the one that most resembles your result. The key will equate this color with the pH number of your soil.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Changing_Your_Soil_pH_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Changing_Your_Soil_pH">Changing Your Soil pH</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_292462ab89" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_292462ab89')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-10-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make your soil less acidic.</b> If your soil pH tested below 7, add a cup of dolomite or quick lime to the soil. Mix well, then retest with your probe. Use this method to slowly change the pH of your soil. Wood ash in moderation helps as well. Both are available at local gardening centers.

<ul>
<li>Follow the advice in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these substances you will need to add to achieve the desired pH. If you need to change your soil pH level more than one full point, contact a local gardening professional. They can help you calibrate your soil so it can be amended most successfully.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_e03432dea7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e03432dea7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-11-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make your soil less alkaline.</b> If your soil pH tested above 7, add a cup of organic matter, such as pine needles, peat moss, or decomposed tree leaves. Then, retest the soil to gauge the new pH. Add additional cups, testing as necessary, until you reach the desired level. Sulfur is very effective as well.

<ul>
<li>Use the instructions in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these additives you will need to add to achieve your desired pH. If your soil needs to be adjusted more than a full pH point, contact a local gardening or landscaping professional. They can help you calibrate your soil to the right level through an on-site evaluation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=105658" href="#/Image:Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_d12aa20b32" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d12aa20b32')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Test Soil pH Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg/aid105658-v4-728px-Test-Soil-pH-Step-12-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Change your soil pH to suit specific plants.</b> For example, add sulfur to a certain area of your garden to encourage beautiful blue blooms on your hydrangeas, which prefer more acidic soils. The pH of your soil does not need to be uniform your entire garden over; feel free to alter it to support different plants. You can consult the Old Farmer’s Almanac to determine the best pH for your particular garden. Some plants prefer a pH of 7 while some fruits favor a lower pH.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="section_text" id="qa">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="386451" data-caid="387324" data-cqid="386468" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1614030" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="13">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I test without vinegar?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can also use cabbage water to get a rough reading of your soil's pH. Cut up one cup of red cabbage. Measure out 2 cups of distilled water into a saucepan, add the red cabbage and simmer it for five minutes. After that, remove the saucepan from heat and let it sit for 30 minutes. Strain away the resulting purple-blue liquid (cabbage water); its pH will be 7. Add 2 teaspoons of the soil you want to test to a jar, then add a few inches of cabbage water before stirring the mix and waiting for 30 minutes. If the sample turns pink, the soil is acidic (has a lower pH); if it turns bluish-green, the soil is basic/alkaline.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>13</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="271598" data-caid="272471" data-cqid="271615" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1611951" data-submitter_id="4309832" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">The picture shows baking soda liquid. How much baking soda do I add to water to make the solution?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/skins/WikiHow/images/80x80_user.png)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Dtown2002">Dtown2002</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You don't use the baking soda to make the solution. The cabbage water is the solution. Putting in the baking soda is just testing to see if it works.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="311936" data-caid="312809" data-cqid="311953" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1377454" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can soil ph be controlled?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">By altering the amount of acids or bases in the soil. if you don't want to make it too acidic, then look out for organic matter and animal droppings.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="90269" data-caid="91142" data-cqid="90286" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="322261" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="10" data-votes_up="27">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What does pH mean?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">pH is the negative log of the H+ ion concentration in water.  Water ionizes slightly to form H+ and OH- ions. Their concentrations are in equilibrium, so that the product of their concentrations always gives the value of 10 to the power negative 14.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>10</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>27</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="44464" data-caid="45337" data-cqid="44481" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="454555" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="10" data-votes_up="25">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What type of soil is the best for the planting of azaleas?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Azaleas love acidic soil and partial shade. Pine trees can be the perfect companion for azaleas. The flowers benefit from the shade, and after the pine needles fall, they begin to decay and release acids into the soil.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why did acid form after I added base and water in the soil container?</div>

<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If soil with distilled water and base gave you acid, then the soil must have been acidic to begin with, and the soil's total amount of acid must have been greater than the amount of base you added.</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes. The pH level will directly affect every plant's nutrient uptake. If the pH is too high or low, your plants won't be able to get the nutrients they need.</div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Record your results. You may need to reference your test results at a later date, as they may change over time.</li>
<li>Prevent contamination (and incorrect readings) by making sure your pH tester probe and your spade are clean. Do not handle soil with your bare hands.</li>
<li>Take multiple soil readings with each test. A minimum of six samples from different parts of your garden is a safe amount.</li>
<li>Some testers present the approximate pH as a color, rather than as a number. In this case, green usually indicates neutral soil; yellow or orange indicates acidic soil; and dark green indicates alkaline soil.</li>
<li>Contact your local agricultural department or extension service office for more information about soil testing or for professional assistance testing your soil.</li>
<li>Make sure the tester is properly calibrated before taking a reading (if you want a more accurate measurement).</li>
<li>pH changes the availability of nutrients for plants. Optimum pH is generally between 5.5 and 7.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>As noted above, the water you pour into the hole can affect your reading if the pH of the water is not neutral. Use distilled water for all testing.</li>
<li>Some testers will function differently than that described in this article. Always make sure to read the manufacturer's instructions carefully to ensure accurate readings.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To test your soil’s pH, first, go online or to your local garden center and buy pH test strips, which are also called litmus paper. Then, take a handful of the soil you want to test and mix it with just enough distilled water to give it the consistency of a milkshake. Next, put the test strip into the dirt mixture and hold it there for 20-30 seconds. Remove it from the dirt and dip it quickly into distilled water to clean it off. Finally, you can determine your soil’s pH by comparing the strip's coloration to the color-coded key that came with the test strips. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For information from our reviewer on testing soil pH by using a commercial test probe, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

title: How to Test Soil pH
content_html:
Dig a small hole in the soil. Use a trowel or spade to dig a hole 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) deep. Break up the soil within the hole and remove any twigs or foreign debris.
Fill the hole with water. Use distilled (not spring) water. You can find this in your local pharmacy. Rainwater is slightly acidic, and bottled or tap water tends to be slightly alkaline. Fill the hole until you have a muddy pool at the bottom.
Insert the test probe into the mud. Make sure your tester is clean and calibrated (for a more exact measurement). Wipe the probe with a tissue or clean cloth, and insert it into the mud.
Hold it there for 60 seconds and take a reading. pH is usually measured on a scale of 1-14, though the tester may not include this entire range.
  • A pH of 7 indicates neutral soil.
  • A pH above 7 indicates alkaline soil.
  • A pH below 7 indicates acidic soil.
Take several measurements in different spots in the garden. A single reading may be an anomaly, so it's good to get an idea of the average pH in a plot. If they're all around the same, take the average and amend the soil accordingly. If one spot is very different than the rest, however, you may need to "spot treat" it.
Purchase pH test strips. Test strips, also known as litmus paper, are a quick and easy way to measure the pH of your soil. You can purchase them online or at your local garden store.[1]
Mix a handful of soil with room-temperature distilled water. Take a handful of the soil you’d like to test and put it in a bowl. Then, pour some distilled water into the bowl until the dirt is the consistency of a milkshake. You can give the mixture a stir to ensure the water is fully incorporated.[2]
Dip a pH test strip in the mixture for 20-30 seconds. Holding your pH test strip at the non-reading end, dip the strip into the dirt mixture for 20-30 seconds. This test time can vary, so consult the directions on your specific test strips to determine the proper dipping time. When the test time is up, lift the pH strip from the water, and dip it briefly in distilled water to clean off the dirt.
Compare your pH strip to the test kit’s key. Use the key included in your pH test kit to read the pH of your soil. Normally this key is color-coded. Compare your strip to the colors available, and select the one that most resembles your result. The key will equate this color with the pH number of your soil.[3]
Make your soil less acidic. If your soil pH tested below 7, add a cup of dolomite or quick lime to the soil. Mix well, then retest with your probe. Use this method to slowly change the pH of your soil. Wood ash in moderation helps as well. Both are available at local gardening centers.
  • Follow the advice in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these substances you will need to add to achieve the desired pH. If you need to change your soil pH level more than one full point, contact a local gardening professional. They can help you calibrate your soil so it can be amended most successfully.[4]
Make your soil less alkaline. If your soil pH tested above 7, add a cup of organic matter, such as pine needles, peat moss, or decomposed tree leaves. Then, retest the soil to gauge the new pH. Add additional cups, testing as necessary, until you reach the desired level. Sulfur is very effective as well.
  • Use the instructions in your commercial test probe kit to determine how much of these additives you will need to add to achieve your desired pH. If your soil needs to be adjusted more than a full pH point, contact a local gardening or landscaping professional. They can help you calibrate your soil to the right level through an on-site evaluation.[5]
Change your soil pH to suit specific plants. For example, add sulfur to a certain area of your garden to encourage beautiful blue blooms on your hydrangeas, which prefer more acidic soils. The pH of your soil does not need to be uniform your entire garden over; feel free to alter it to support different plants. You can consult the Old Farmer’s Almanac to determine the best pH for your particular garden. Some plants prefer a pH of 7 while some fruits favor a lower pH.
